title: bash: please use dpkg-buildflags to retrieve compiler options (including hardening flags)

sentences.text: I'm currently working on cross-building bits of Debian and bash fails to build.
The reason is simple: debian/rules hard-codes the use of "gcc" as the compiler to use.
The trivial patch here detects a cross-build and works for me:
>  Build-Depends: autoconf, autotools-dev, patch, bison, libncurses5-dev,
> - texinfo, debhelper (>= 5), texi2html, locales, gettext, sharutils, time, xz-utils
> + texinfo, debhelper (>= 5), texi2html, locales, gettext, sharutils, time, xz-utils, dpkg-dev (>= 1.16.1)
Long line, but no big deal.

I was surprised something like this is necessary, but after thinking about it a little it makes sense --- after all, different packages sometimes want to use different compilers, so dpkg-buildpackage doesn't have enough information to set CC on its own.
Would it make sense to just use 'CC = $(DEB_HOST_GNU_TYPE)-gcc' unconditionally, for simplicity?
Unfortunately, "export" statements don't affect the environment of $(shell) substitutions (bug#327154).
By the way, what about CPPFLAGS?
Micronit: the command feels more natural with all options ($(CFLAGS)
Warning: handling of configure args is a little hacky.
build: before-build bash-build static-build preinst-build check
I guess you've taken this patch from the Launchpad branch for the Ubuntu bash package?
I was confused to have this come up for discussion when I haven't submitted it yet to Debian (or even uploaded it to Ubuntu).
On Sat, Nov 12, 2011 at 11:38:36PM -0600, Jonathan Nieder wrote:

> I was surprised something like this is necessary, but after thinking > about it a little it makes sense --- after all, different packages > sometimes want to use different compilers, so dpkg-buildpackage > doesn't have enough information to set CC on its own.
> Would it make sense to just use 'CC = $(DEB_HOST_GNU_TYPE)-gcc' > unconditionally, for simplicity?
I'm not confident that this is guaranteed to give the same results in all cases as calling gcc directly.
--host + --build results in cross-compiling behavior even when not cross-compiling, but I don't know how much of this is due to autoconf itself vs.
> Unfortunately, "export" statements don't affect the environment of > $(shell) substitutions (bug#327154).
> By the way, what about CPPFLAGS?
Not used in the existing source package, so I didn't touch this.
> Micronit: the command feels more natural with all options ($(CFLAGS)
Warning: handling of configure args is > a little hacky.
As long as you're changing these options, you might as well fix them to be autotools-compliant (i.e., passing --host *only* when cross-compiling, and
could probably do with some rationale why it's ok for these to be removed.
Steve Langasek                   Give me a lever long enough and a Free OS Debian Developer                   to set it on, and I can move the world.
> I guess you've taken this patch from the Launchpad branch for the Ubuntu > bash package?
Sorry, I should have mentioned so.
> As long as you're changing these options, you might as well fix them to be > autotools-compliant (i.e., passing --host *only* when cross-compiling, and
> On Sat, Nov 12, 2011 at 11:38:36PM -0600, Jonathan Nieder wrote:
> could probably do with some rationale why it's ok for these to be removed.
It's because they're set by configure already.

I also considered setting LDFLAGS and CPPFLAGS on the commandline alongside CFLAGS instead, but bash's Makefile.in is not designed to allow overriding LDFLAGS on the command line (whereas overriding LDFLAGS in configure works well).
retitle -1 bash: please use dpkg-buildflags to retrieve compiler options (including hardening flags)
> As long as you're changing these options, you might as well fix them to be > autotools-compliant (i.e., passing --host *only* when cross-compiling, and
Ok, here's a rerolled pair of patches that does that.
Steve McIntyre's patch seems good already and independent of all this, so I've left it out.
